title: Ryan Holiday: Finding stillness amidst chaos
content: Ryan Holiday, bestselling author and author of Daily Stoic, discusses practical ways to find stillness and apply the insights of stoic philosophy in the midst of COVID-19 chaos. Ryan discusses the importance of taking back a feeling of control, the benefits of structure and routine, and the idea of being prepared for anything.

title: The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: The Impact of Stress on Chronic Illness, Dementia, Depression, and More
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the physiology of a stress response and why it’s ingrained in our DNA.

title: Individual Variation in the Response to Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about individual variation in the response to stress and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: The Impact of Stress on Memory and Health
content: Robert Sapolsky discusses the role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia, as well as the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: The Impact of Stress on Cancer, Atherosclerosis, Dementia, Addiction, and Depression
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: The potential positive of adversity
content: The only potential positive of a dramatic setback, adversity, or obstacle is that it is a chance to see things differently or look at things differently.

title: Insights from the famous stoics amidst COVID-19
content: The physical risk to people and the uncertainty around that (we still don’t know the denominator in terms of total cases so we don’t really know the death rate). Churchill might suggest putting some space between yourself and the media hysteria. Marcus Aurelius actually lived through the Antonine Plague in Rome which lasted for 15 years … and much of his writing occurred during this time. As a leader, Ryan says Marcus brought calmness, clear headedness, and courage.

title: The consequences of socially isolating nature of a pandemic
content: David Brooks wrote in the NY Times: Pandemics Kill Compassion, Too. The gist of this article was to point out that there are certain externalities that are very difficult that can be uniting (think post-9/11).

title: Stoicism and pandemics
content: Stoic philosophy was actually born from a time when pandemics were very real in addition to exile, war, marriage problems, cheating business partner, broken leg without the same healthcare we have today. The central precept of stoicism is basically that we don’t control what has happened or what is happening, but we control how we respond to those things.

title: Lessons from Winston Churchill's life
content: Churchill has the most up and down life you could imagine … going from political exile to world leader and Nobel Prize winner. Yet somehow, Churchill managed to keep pushing forward and went on to do amazing things. He was also able to focus on the task ahead rather than worrying about the past. First, it turns out, he was a creature of habit, routine, and discipline even in the most stressful of times. Secondly, he made time for hobbies and time away from “work”.

title: Re-energize
content: Ryan says that if you use this “down time” to detach and rest and rejuvenate, there is nothing wrong with that  (if you actually emerge well rested). The point though is that it should be deliberate.

title: Re-evaluate and try new things
content: Now is also time to really question a lot of things about our lives—the decisions we make about, the businesses that we have, the goals that we’ve been striving towards. We should also try new things – especially things that we may not have ever made time for.

title: Having a plan for anything
content: Stoicism teaches the importance of being prepared for the worst. It’s not always pleasant to imagine things going wrong but what you really don’t want is to get caught off guard. Because as Murphy’s Law says, what can go wrong does.

title: A flaw in America’s setup
content: Ryan says the way the America is set up with 50 strong states backed by a strong central government has us prepared for segregated catastrophes (e.g., helping when California has wildfires, or New Orleans is hit with a hurricane). But as we’ve seen, it was not set up well to handle a massive, interconnected problem affecting all 50 states. Peter hopes we learn from this as a country… perhaps to decentralize command to allow for individual states to take responsibility for being prepared and to be able to make their own decisions.

title: Asserting control and using routine to find stillness in an environment not conducive for it
content: Ryan stresses the importance of asserting control in your life. Ryan, for example, has decided to wake up to an alarm every morning even though he could sleep as much as he wants and sort of just “kill” another day. He is being deliberate about his time.

title: Finding ways to assert control in difficult situations
content: During his imprisonment, Rubin decided to take control over every little tiny thing he could. He decided that how he was going to wrap his head around the lack of control that he had was he was going to assert control and other ways. And I think that’s an interesting approach that might be worth thinking about for people. So, how can you find some ways to assert agency in the midst of all of this powerlessness and, and I think you’ll find that that’s really reassuring.

title: The importance of exercise for mental and physical health
content: Exercise is really important for mental and physical health. Your gym being closed might make it harder but there are apps available to help you make due with what you have at home. Worst case scenario, get out there and take a walk. Taking 20 minutes to exercise or simply move around pays enormous dividends, says Peter, physiologically, psychologically, and spiritually. Ryan’s wife uses the Future personal training app.

title: The benefits of journaling and finding purpose during difficult times
content: Stoics were a big proponent of journaling. Ryan recommends it to people … he describes the benefit as follows: “I’m really trying to use it as a place to sort of remind myself and reiterate to myself, like how I want to be inside this. It’s sort of reminders of like, ‘Hey, you’re worried about X, Y, and Z. You know, one way not to think about that is to think about other people instead.’ So I’m trying to just like sort of buck myself up a little bit in the morning, kind of remind myself of what’s important to me. I think journaling is not this, just this stream of conscious sort of thing you’re doing. It’s not performing for history. To me it should be, it’s like, it’s like playing scales on the guitar or on the piano. You’re running yourself through it over and over again. So that it gets more imputed into your memory and kind of into your being.” Peter tells the story about how his 11 year old daughter was having a hard time comprehending how she was going to have to stay at home and “shelter in place”. Purpose, goal setting, and projects During this time, we should be asking ourselves, “What goals or things can we give ourselves (and our kids) that we can throw ourselves into that allows us to sort of escape from this a little bit?”

title: Ryan's concerns and hopes for the future
content: He hopes it redefines the role of the US president and redefines the importance of a lot of the alliances and relationships internationally that we have with a lot of, a lot of different countries. We should hopefully rethink how we do business with other countries and perhaps bring our manufacturing back to the US instead of relying on China. Ryan is actually worried that the revolutionary extremes on both the left and right will “seize upon the wreckage that emerges from this and are actually empowered.” Ryan is worried for the millennial generation who were starting to sort of mature (saving up, good jobs, buying homes, etc.) and they’ve been hit by another economic disaster.

title: Peter's worries about the impact of COVID-19
content: Peter is worried about the short-term impact of COVID-19 on healthcare systems, the lack of data to understand the virus's impact, and the accumulating debt of the US. He is concerned about the doctors who have to make difficult decisions on who to treat with limited resources.

title: Ryan's work and messages about stoicism and stillness
content: Ryan's work and messages about stoicism and stillness can be followed through the Daily Stoic newsletter, Daily Dad newsletter, and Twitter accounts @dailystoic and @ryanholiday. His books, 'Obstacle is the Way' and 'Stillness is the Key,' are recommended for those who may be struggling during this time.
